intro: Cuminum maroccanum, commonly known as Moroccan cumin, is an annual herb native to North Africa. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its aromatic seeds. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with finely divided, fern-like leaves. Its small, yellowish-green flowers appear in umbels, and the seeds are harvested when dry and mature. The botanical features of Cuminum maroccanum make it well-suited for cultivation in temperate climates with well-drained soil.
